td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

td.h3: Schools Closed through the End of the School Year
td.p: Today, April 16, the Governor announced actions to continue keeping us safe and minimize the impact of COVID-19 on the state and our communities. These actions include the extension of the Safer at Home order until May 26, 2020 as well as the closing of Wisconsin schools, both public and private, for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.

We will be following our current school calendar and each school will continue to communicate with you and provide the necessary learning tools. At this time, the District is tentatively planning for our traditional graduation on Sunday, May 31 at 2:00 PM and our summer school offerings.
td.h4: Mental Health and Other Student Support Services

p.meta: For those of you who need the support of our student services team, please visit this link to learn how they can support you. The District and schools will continue to provide updates as the journey continues.

td.p: For any families with children age 18 and younger who would like FREE meals during this school closure, we are offering two ways for you to access meal service. If you are wanting to take advantage of this service, please check out this link to learn more.
For students in grades 4-12 digital learning will be the primary means of delivering instruction. If non-digital access is necessary for your student(s), schools will be providing learning packets.
Students in grades PK-3 will be provided learning packets. Some grade levels will also have digital options available (Smarty Ants, Dream Box, RAZ Kids, etc.)

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our district families and staff is our top priority. Please watch for the following symptoms in your family. Contact a physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurse and the Wood County Health Department, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

img.alt: How to Talk to Kids about Coronavirus

li.span: For those families that cannot pick up meals at Humke Elementary School, we are offering bus stop deliveries.
